column4: Hi all. I'm currently running Mac OS X 10.6 and I want to switch to Ubuntu 12.04 as my primary OS. However, I'm going to keep OS X on another partition for when I need to sync some of my iOS devices (iPad 3 and iPod 4, which aren't compatible with libimobiledevice). I have a 1.5TB external hard drive that I need to be able to read and write to from both Mac and Ubuntu, so I'm wondering what filesystem to use. I'd rather not use FAT32 because of th
limitations. What would you guys suggest?
Shrink your MAC partition MacOSX has to tools for that and then install Ubuntu beside
yes but I need read/write support on the external HD. What filesystem should I use for the external hard disk so I can read and write to it from both OSs?
As far as I know osx uses hfs+ which should be at least readable under ubuntu
I know but I need writable lol. =P Would HFS without journaling work?
Apparently it works readwrite as well. sometimes disks are readonly because they where not unmounted correctly a fsck.hfsplus /dev/yourdisk you correct that
is that new in 12.04? Because I always remember having to install packages like hfsprogs
of course you need the hfsplus progs :)
so I just sudo apt-get install hfsprogs and then it should work as a plug and play drive like in OS X?
I just need something that I can get up and running quickly so everything works in my work environment.
I think so but haven't tried it
ok. I have it partitioned as exFAT right now and I remember that it was only read only, soâ€¦ Well, I guess I'll give HFS+ a shot. Thanks!
